content.body: i accidentally wrote instead of and the validator said "error fatal: Too many messages" after spewing about one error per paragraph in html5
i may have to admit that the html5 parser's recovery is not necessarily what a validator should try to do

Hixie: I found obsolete attributes useful today: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/performance-mistake/
Hixie: what would have been the right way to do the table cell alignment?
huh? is the W3C establishing a new *Activity* for EOT?
hsivonen: url? (that eot thing)
virtuelv: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2008Aug/att-0010/EOT-charter-draft-1.html
shall refrain from commenting further
Hixie: "and required that if two of these attributes are specified (or if all three are specified, in text/html), they have the same value." -- afaict it's not allowed to specify all 3 per the spec
"Authors must not use the xml:lang attribute (that is, the lang attribute with the xml prefix in the http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace namespace) in HTML documents."
xml:lang causes so much trouble
in retrospect, XML 1.0 should have reserved id, class and lang
hsivonen: i've came to that conclusion too
s/came/come/
decides to start measuring the performance cost of the HTML5 tree construction layer
hsivonen: i think we may want to expose charoff on col or td
hsivonen: but there's not much point before UAs have any intention of implementing it
zcorpan: yeah i guess you can't include all three on one element without violating another rule before worrying about the values anyway
Hixie: how about getting to use align conformingly in the mean time?
what's wrong with the css equivalent?
td + td { text-align: right; }
anyway bed time now
Hixie: that violates the separation of content and style. I the rules in the style sheet should not have to depend on what number of columns my tables have and which columns have which alignment
hsivonen: interesting the results you got with your performance changes
hsivonen: because in hubbub, I was briefly toying with having a buffer only when required and switching to it if NULs/CRs/entities were encountered
hsivonen: turns out it added a lot of extra macros, removed clarity, and it ended up easier and about as fast to do unconditional buffer writes
takkaria: I guess it's comforting that C is like that, too, and this isn't just a Java thing ;-)
I wish I knew x86 well enough to speculate on why it's the case
today, I measured the perf cost of the HTML5 tree builder compared to an XML-ish tree builder
I'll blog about that later
executive summary: the Validator.nu HTML Parser's tokenizer is almost as fast as Xerces without the HTML tree builder complexity
that's pretty speedy
Hubbub's tokeniser tokenises HTML5 in about 0.5s
which is something like 5MB/s
however, libxml tokenises and produces a tree in 0.8s.  so there's quite a lot of scope for improvement, or so I hope
takkaria: do you count IO when benchmarking the tokenizer?
I have some perf tests around which basically mmap() a file into memory and then pass the memory thus mapped to libxml2/hubbub
I guess I could read an entire file properly rather than letting the OS do it, but I don't think it would make that much difference
at some point it would be nice to do proper somewhat-scientific benchmarks, though right now getting hubbub fully-funtional takes more priority
with Java, IO details make a huge difference
which is why I run benchmarks from RAM when I don't want to benchmark IO
(I already tweaked IO earlier)
(It might not be a bad idea to rerun tests with IO included)
my benchmarking is really unscientific, and consists of writing test apps and running them through `time` on the command-line
otoh, mmap() after a couple of runs results in fairly unchanging data, so it's good enough for me
I do timing inside Java and warm the VM up first
yeah, you have the advantage there :)
performance tuning on HotSpot is pretty annoying
because doing the wrong thing can lead to HotSpot not JITting stuff
which means about tenth the performance
I wonder how much I could speed up the tokenizer if I removed all the run-time configurability
JohnResig, yt?

oh, no, that's not it.

Because no one ever wrote any open source software that needs threads...
jgraham, who said that?
Lachy: Shannon on the whatwg list. You may have stopped reading the thread...
yeah, I haven't read much on whatwg lately
What do you guys think: 10 GETs vs. 1 GET + 50k
I would reply and mention the existence of Erlang and use cases for long running background tasks for things like web-based image editors but I don't think it would help
50kb?
suspects that 1 get + 50kb would be faster for most people
If that was the question
But I have no reason for thinking that
csarven: ? use case?
but in general, unless the 1 request locks up the browser/page UI, I'd propose going for it
10 requests add at the very least 3kb extra of data to download
jgraham virtuelv I'm applying data: URI scheme to images in CSS.
every time someone mentions Erlang I reach for my gun
roc: ?
is quite scared
too many people seem to believe that Erlang invented message passing
csarven: I'm probably slow, given that my body is in a different timezone than the one I'm actually in, without having travelled across timezones
csarven: but you're including images using data:
if you have 50 K of image data in data: URI's, I'd say you're doing it wrong
roc: I don't know who invented message passing but Erlang is probably the most famous example of a system that uses it heavilly, right?
wrong
So what is right?
well, thanks to the Erlang fanboys you may in fact be right at this point, but that's self-fulfilling ignorance
roc: A lot of fame seems to be based around that concept...
Anyway, I am curious about the other, better, examples
csarven: if your stylesheet is big, as 50 kB is, you are at some point going to end up with FOUC on a slow connection
csarven: I'd rather see if the images could be combined, using some variant of CSS sprites, to keep the number of requests down
Mach was extremely famous and uses message passing
virtuelv I'm already using CSS sprites
It appears to be that the resulting total weight of the page is 50k more when I use data:

roc: That's a microkernel, right? I guess it wouldn't be the right example to use if you were trying to convince a skeptic that message passing is a good idea on the web (but I don't disagree that it's pretty famous)
but well before that, there were well-known programming models like actors and CSP that are focused on shared-nothing message passing
csarven: then you have a lot of image data, ~250kb, or so?
a possible optimization at that point is to store the images at a different domain/subdomain

hm, or I might be off here, the overhead is 3/2
or so
